titleStmt.title: Letter from Edith Nalle to John G. Neihardt, November 30, 1960
titleStmt.author: Nalle, Edith

publicationStmt.authority: The Papers of John G. Neihardt

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Nalle, Edith
bibl.title: Letter from Edith Nalle to John G. Neihardt

revisionDesc.change: Weakly, Laura K. transcription and encoding

div1.fw:
Atlanta Chicago Dallas San Francisco London Manila
Brett Macmillan, Galt, Ontario
The Macmillan Company
Cable Address Pachamac New York Publishers Telephone Oregon 5-4000
Sixty Fifth Avenue New York 11, N.Y.
div1.p: First of all, let me tell you how much I enjoyed listening to you talk at the October meeting of the Westerners. I hadn't heard a spell-binder speak for a long time, I'd forgotten what it was like. I'd like to urge you to write something more for Macmillan, but I somehow feel this is a vain hope, that if you wanted to you'd be doing it without any urging from me.

Listening to you made most of the Western material that comes across my desk seem drab and second rate and because of this I am writing you to ask for your advice. What should be done in the field of Western writing and Americana that isn't being done? Do you, in your travels and at home, come upon new writers who should be encouraged? How can I instill in the writers on Macmillan's current list the same spirit that infused your poetry? (I guess that last question is unanswerable.)

Anyway, I certainly don't mean to bother you, and I know you are busy, but I would be very grateful if you had any advice to pass on to an energetic, new, but still somewhat undirected editor in a field you know so well.

closer.signed:
Edith Nalle
Assistant Editor
Trade Editorial Department
